title.value: PyNM: a Lightweight Python implementation of Normative Modeling
title.justification: The title directly reflects the primary subject of the research paper, which is the development and explanation of PyNM.
title.quote: PyNM: a Lightweight Python implementation of Normative Modeling

extractions.description: This paper presents PyNM, a lightweight Python tool designed to facilitate and implement Normative Modeling (NM), making it accessible and easy to use. Normative Modeling allows for the analysis of individual deviations from normative ranges within a population, offering an alternative approach to traditional case-control methods in neuroimaging and psychiatry.

type.justification: The paper focuses on the implementation and practical application of the PyNM tool, a software framework for Normative Modeling.
type.quote: PyNM is a lightweight python implementation of Normative Modeling making it approachable and easy to adopt.

name.justification: The primary research field is Neuroimaging, as the tool and approach are intended for use in this field, specifically aiding in the understanding of psychiatric conditions through brain imaging analysis.
name.quote: The majority of studies in neuroimaging and psychiatry are focussed on case-control analysis.

name.justification: Psychiatry is a related field where Normative Modeling can be applied, as mentioned in the paper.
name.quote: However, case-control relies on well-defined groups which is more the exception than the rule in biology. Psychiatric conditions are diagnosed based on symptoms alone, which makes for heterogeneity at the biological level.

name.justification: The loess_normative_model is explicitly mentioned as one of the models integrated into the PyNM package.

is_contributed.justification: The model is part of the PyNM package, which is the main contribution of the paper.
is_contributed.quote: PyNM includes five models from various backends in a unified interface.

is_executed.justification: The paper does not mention the execution environment for the model.
is_executed.quote: There is no specific quote identifying the execution environment.

is_compared.justification: The paper does not provide a numerical comparison of this model with others.
is_compared.quote: There is no specific quote about numerical comparison.

referenced_paper_title.value: Generalized additive models for location, scale and shape
referenced_paper_title.justification: The GAMLSS model implementation in PyNM refers to the GAMLSS package from R, which is documented in the literature.
referenced_paper_title.quote: and includes a wrapper for GAMLSS (Rigby & Stasinopoulos, 2005) from R that is otherwise not yet available in python

name.justification: The model is mentioned as an available alternative in the field to PyNM.
name.quote: To the author’s knowledge, PCNtoolkit (Marquand et al., 2021) is the only other available package for Normative Modeling.

is_contributed.justification: This model is not part of the main contribution of PyNM.
is_contributed.quote: To the author’s knowledge, PCNtoolkit (Marquand et al., 2021) is the only other available package for Normative Modeling.

is_executed.justification: There is no information regarding whether PCNtoolkit is executed within this study.
is_executed.quote: There is no specific quote about execution in the context of this paper.

is_compared.justification: The paper mentions PCNtoolkit as an alternative but does not compare it numerically with PyNM or any models within.
is_compared.quote: To the author's knowledge, PCNtoolkit (Marquand et al., 2021) is the only other available package for Normative Modeling.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for PCNtoolkit is clearly mentioned in the references section.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Marquand, A. F., Rutherford, S., Kia, S. M., Wolfers, T., Fraza, C., Dinga, R., & Zabihi, M. (2021). PCNToolkit (0.20). Zenodo.

name.justification: The GAMLSS package from R is mentioned as a part of the PyNM implementation.
name.quote: and includes a wrapper for GAMLSS (Rigby & Stasinopoulos, 2005) from R that is otherwise not yet available in python
